Answer: See the images below:This is what is called ‚Äúhostile architecture‚Äù, widely practiced in USA, one of the richest nations of the world. They are ‚Äúhostile‚Äù to their poor and destitute. They take extra care to ensure that the homeless amongst them, the needy amongst them do not sleep on the pavements, in the parks, on the benches.I understand that areas crowded by the homeless smell of faeces and urine, drug use can become rampant. But this is no solution. They are in dire circumstances and they need care and not the hostility of those who are placed better in their lives.In India, we are not verySee the images below:This is what is called ‚Äúhostile architecture‚Äù, widely practiced in USA, one of the richest nations of the world. They are ‚Äúhostile‚Äù to their poor and destitute. They take extra care to ensure that the homeless amongst them, the needy amongst them do not sleep on the pavements, in the parks, on the benches.I understand that areas crowded by the homeless smell of faeces and urine, drug use can become rampant. But this is no solution. They are in dire circumstances and they need care and not the hostility of those who are placed better in their lives.In India, we are not very rich, most of us barely make ends meet. Most of us do not live the lives of abundance. But we have a special compassion for our weak and downtrodden. We serve free food to millions upon millions all across the country through community kitchens.This, I think, is unique to the Indian subcontinent.

Answer: I am anNow this is the main page of a largest selling News Daily in India ‚ÄúThe Times of India‚Äù onThis is Jesus and couple of kids celebrating Easter.Why would the Largest selling English Newspaper daily bother to draw a mini art of Jesus at a place where it could have posted an advertisement which would have fetched more revenue?We have two National Holidays for Christmas and Good Friday. Most of my Hindu brethren don‚Äôt know much about Good Friday yet they wish us Happy Good Friday on WhI am anNow this is the main page of a largest selling News Daily in India ‚ÄúThe Times of India‚Äù onThis is Jesus and couple of kids celebrating Easter.Why would the Largest selling English Newspaper daily bother to draw a mini art of Jesus at a place where it could have posted an advertisement which would have fetched more revenue?We have two National Holidays for Christmas and Good Friday. Most of my Hindu brethren don‚Äôt know much about Good Friday yet they wish us Happy Good Friday on WhatsApp (Guys, it is a sad day for us).As far as government is concerned, it tries its best to protect and uplift India‚Äôs minorities.For example, all major churches are fortified and heavily guarded during Christmas and Easter to prevent any untoward incident.In 2015 some miscreants broke the window glasses of a church in Delhi. And soon it became the prime time debate. A Union Minister personally visited the place and assured security. Such events happen to temples on regular basis, but I have never seen a visit from any Union Minister.Please don‚Äôt get me wrong!Imagine this, instead of Sri Lanka, on Easter‚Äôs eve if Indian Churches were attacked by ISIS and if 300+ Indian Christians were killed. Probably this government would have declared war on ISIS and decimated them .My only question is why would a government and its people work so hard to preserve and uplift a very small, scattered section of people that is barely 2.5%.So, No, My India is not intolerant.

In 2010, the median age of Indian Muslims was 22, compared with 26 for Hindus and 28 for Christians. Likewise, Muslim women have an average of 3.2 children per woman, compared with 2.5 for Hindus and 2.3 for Christians.Due to these factors, India‚Äôs Muslim community will expand faster than its Hindu population, rising from 14.4% in 2010 to 18.4% in 2050. But, even with this increase, Hindus will make up more than three-in-four Indians (76.7%) in 2050. Indeed, the number of Hindus in India will still be larger than the five largest Muslim populations in the world‚Äôs biggest Muslim countries (India, Pakistan, Indonesia, Nigeria and Bangladesh) combined.Below is the World Demographics Researchers data:We need to control our population..!!Peace ü§üüôè

Answer: Did you know that the number 4 is designated as the black hole number?Think of any word, name, thing etc.For e.g. the word ‚Äò‚Äòmathematics‚Äù, has eleven letters.Now ‚Äòeleven‚Äô in turn has six letters.‚ÄòSix‚Äô has three letters.‚ÄòThree‚Äô has five letters.‚ÄòFive‚Äô has four letters.And how many letters does ‚Äòfour‚Äô have?FOUR!Think of any other word and you‚Äôll arrive at the same dead end.Black hole number, people.This was something really cool taught by my teacher in high school!

Answer: AzerbaijanWinter of 1956, Baku, a capital of one of the Republics of USSR.Thousands of citizens stand on the roads of the city whispering ‚Äúfinally we will see him‚Äù.A month before, the news of Raj Kapoor's visit of Moscow created a boom in Azerbaijan. People started sending letters to Central Political Bireux of Azerbaijan SSR with only one message: ‚Äúan Indian legend must come to Azerbaijan‚Äù.Only twice people of Soviet Baku went to the streets to greet someone: first was Raj Kapoor and the second was Leonid Brejnev (Secretary General of USSR).Raj Kapoor and people of BakuSorry for the quality oAzerbaijanWinter of 1956, Baku, a capital of one of the Republics of USSR.Thousands of citizens stand on the roads of the city whispering ‚Äúfinally we will see him‚Äù.A month before, the news of Raj Kapoor's visit of Moscow created a boom in Azerbaijan. People started sending letters to Central Political Bireux of Azerbaijan SSR with only one message: ‚Äúan Indian legend must come to Azerbaijan‚Äù.Only twice people of Soviet Baku went to the streets to greet someone: first was Raj Kapoor and the second was Leonid Brejnev (Secretary General of USSR).Raj Kapoor and people of BakuSorry for the quality of the photoAzerbaijan was called ‚ÄúLittle India‚Äù by other Soviet Republics after this incident.Since 1950s, Indian culture started spreading within the whole USSR, the reason was obvious: Communist party wanted to replace west cinematography, and India was the best choice.However, only in Soviet Azerbaijan, Indian movies became more popular than the Soviet movies what heads of the USSR didn't expect.As a result, Indian movies in USSR were translated only into two languages: Azerbaijani for Azerbaijan and Russian for the rest 14 Soviet Republics.‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.Untill 1922, Azerbaijan was a centre of Hindu pilgrimage which left a unique for the Caucasus the Indian heritage in our country.Such as:The temple of Ateshgah built in 12th century by Hindu pilgrimsThe caravanserai Multani in Baku built by pilgrims from Multan (today's Pakistan)The caravanserai in Sheki built by Delhi pilgrimsAll three today are included in the World UNESCO heritage list.‚Ä¶.Today, we have Indian movie weeks at cinemas of the country, Indian days in Azerbaijan (this year it was last week), Color Festival of Holi (usually we do it in summer but last two years we did it twice, in March and summer)India was one of the first countries which recognized our independence in 1991Thanks, Bharat!

Answer: Guys, meet Porbandar, Porbandar, meet guys. Just in case you all are meeting for the first time, please be civil - say hello and kemcho :)On 2nd October 1869 - Mohandas Gandhi was born in this area - no, that‚Äôs not the interesting fact - have some patience‚Ä¶:)12 years before the birth of Mohandas Gandhi, Porbandar, a princely state, was ruled by Maharaja Rana Sahib Vikramatji Khimojiraj, who enjoyed a hereditary 13 gun salute from the British (Like dozens of other princely states of India, the Maharaja, took part in the First War of Indian Independence - 1857, sidinGuys, meet Porbandar, Porbandar, meet guys. Just in case you all are meeting for the first time, please be civil - say hello and kemcho :)On 2nd October 1869 - Mohandas Gandhi was born in this area - no, that‚Äôs not the interesting fact - have some patience‚Ä¶:)12 years before the birth of Mohandas Gandhi, Porbandar, a princely state, was ruled by Maharaja Rana Sahib Vikramatji Khimojiraj, who enjoyed a hereditary 13 gun salute from the British (Like dozens of other princely states of India, the Maharaja, took part in the First War of Indian Independence - 1857, siding with the British.During the 1857 struggle against the British, the Wagheras of Dwarka revoltedThe British needed help - they sought assistance from all the princely states of Saurashtra region - The Maharaja of Porbandar obliged.State of Porbandar sent a small army, which managed to surroundThe soldiers from Porbandar who helped crush this revolt, were ably lead by the Deewan of Porbandar - one Mr. Kaba Gandhi, officially known as Karamchand Uttamchand GandhiOnly if he knew, what his 4th child will grow up to be :)Thank you for reading. Cheers and peace.

Answer: Ever wondered why there are revolving doors at the entrances of big buildings?Appears to be trouble during excessive movement of people‚Ä¶isn‚Äôt it??Well there is a reason for that bulky thing to get installed at the entrances.Revolving doors allowOpening a hinged or sliding door even for a brief period will result in tremendous amount of heat exchange between the internal and external temperatures, especially in extreme weather conditions.A revolving door prevents this energy loss as there is never a pointEver wondered why there are revolving doors at the entrances of big buildings?Appears to be trouble during excessive movement of people‚Ä¶isn‚Äôt it??Well there is a reason for that bulky thing to get installed at the entrances.Revolving doors allowOpening a hinged or sliding door even for a brief period will result in tremendous amount of heat exchange between the internal and external temperatures, especially in extreme weather conditions.A revolving door prevents this energy loss as there is never a point where the air can flow freely between in and out of the lobby.Save energy for better tomorrow :)

Answer: I had two childhood friends (brothers) who were very bright.We hung out on the same playground, they always were very witty and funny.They had the most interesting ideas. Just by the dynamic conversations we had, I knew they were smart.But when I asked them how they did each term in school, they shrugged, D‚Äôs, C‚Äôs.It made no sense. They were fully capable of great marks.Additionally, they frequently got into fights at school, spent time in detention, and seemed not to care.But, as an adult looking back now, I have much more clarity.When I went over to their house for sleepovers, or to just hanI had two childhood friends (brothers) who were very bright.We hung out on the same playground, they always were very witty and funny.They had the most interesting ideas. Just by the dynamic conversations we had, I knew they were smart.But when I asked them how they did each term in school, they shrugged, D‚Äôs, C‚Äôs.It made no sense. They were fully capable of great marks.Additionally, they frequently got into fights at school, spent time in detention, and seemed not to care.But, as an adult looking back now, I have much more clarity.When I went over to their house for sleepovers, or to just hang out, both of their parents would be reclining in the living room smoking cigarettes, watching TV.I don‚Äôt recall their parents ever asking about homework, them cleaning their rooms, doing anything productive. The boys never had any sort of structure.The worst part: no repercussions for bad grades or misbehavior.It‚Äôs baffling because what parent doesn‚Äôt understand the importance of consequences? And these parents weren‚Äôt an anomaly. There are so many like this in the world.Both of those boys are now grown.They both are high school dropouts.They both work dismal, menial, low wage jobs on the path to nowhere.It is quite unfortunate - because they, like many kids, were capable of so much more.I‚Äôd wager, one of the great predictors of success is having strong parents, who hold their kids to a standard, with a system of rules, rewards, punishments, encouragement, all with an undercurrent of love, to help that child be the best he or she can be.One of the greatest tragedies in life is that of wasted potential.
